utterance.speaker: Howard (on the phone)
utterance.content: Yeah, I miss you, too, sweetie. Listen, I got to go, but I’ll see you tonight? Okay. Bye-bye. Yeah, bye-bye. No, you hang up first. Hello?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Dude, I’m glad you finally got a girlfriend, but do you have to do all that lovey-dovey stuff in front of those of us who don’t?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Actually, he might have to. There’s an economic concept known as a positional good in which an object is only valued by the possessor because it’s not possessed by others. The term was coined in 1976 by economist Fred Hirsch to replace the more colloquial, but less precise neener-neener.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: That’s not true. My happiness is not dependent on my best friend being miserable and alone.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Although, I’d be lying if I said it wasn’t a little bit of a perk.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Who’s miserable and alone?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Me.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh. I used to be like that. Then I got a girlfriend.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: In pre-1976 terms, neener-neener.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hey, what are you and Bernadette doing for your first Valentine’s Day?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Yeah, I am pulling out all the stops. There’s a $39.95 lover’s special at P.F. Chang’s. Egg rolls, dumplings, bottomless wok, and you get your picture taken on the big marble horse out front.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Given that Saint Valentine was a third century Roman priest who was stoned and beheaded, wouldn’t a more appropriate celebration of the evening be taking one’s steady gal to witness a brutal murder?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I understand your point, but given a choice, Jews always go with Chinese food.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Well, if anyone’s interested, I’ll be spending this Valentine’s Day the same way I spend every Valentine’s Day. Buying a rotisserie chicken from the supermarket, taking it home, standing over the sink and eating it out of the package with my bare hands like an animal.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, so to sum up: one giant marble horse, one asinine comment, one lonely man and his chicken. And let’s see, who’s left? Oh, that’s right. My plans. Isn’t anyone going to ask?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Fine, tell us you’re going to have sex with Penny.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: That’s not what I was going to tell you.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: It’s okay. I don’t mind hearing about your sex life. It’s his that bugs me.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Guess who the university is sending to Switzerland to attend a conference and see the CERN supercollider on February 14?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Professor Norton, although, God knows why. He hasn’t published anything of note since he won that Nobel Prize.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Actually, Professor Norton can’t make it. He threw his back out rock climbing.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I heard he threw his back out climbing on his new girlfriend.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: The big-boobed weather girl on Channel 2?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: That’s the one.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: In any case, they’re asking me to fill in for him.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: In Switzerland or with the big-boobed weather girl?

utterance.speaker: Leonard

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh, man!

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: No way, dude!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: This is incredible! I’m so happy, I’m not even going to question their judgment in picking you. I’m just going to run home and start packing.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Why wouldn’t you take Penny?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I am taking Penny.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Oh. Well, then I anticipate an awkward situation when you get home.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sheldon, you got a minute?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Of course, my good friend. Come in. Help me out, which ski hat says après supercollider?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sheldon, I’m not taking you to Switzerland.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, of course you are. Who else would you take?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Penny.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: What? That’s absurd. Penny has no interest in subatomic particle research.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yes, but it’ll be Valentine’s Day. We can go sightseeing and skiing and make love in front of a roaring fire in the shadow of the snowcapped Alps.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: But Penny has no interest in subatomic particle research.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I’m sorry, Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Sorry? I’ve been dreaming about going to the Large Hadron Collider since I was nine years old.

utterance.speaker: Leonard

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Shame on you! That’s no dream for a scientist!

utterance.speaker: Penny

utterance.content: Oh. Wow. Okay. Let’s see. We’ve got, uh, milk chocolate, Swiss cheese, fondue. My lactose-intolerant boyfriend is going to eat all this, then I’m going to climb on his back and rocket to the moon?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No. But it does involve air travel. Okay, um, let me slice this Swiss cheese with my Swiss army knife, and then you can wash it down with a cup of Swiss Miss instant cocoa.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, I’m starting to think Swiss is key here.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Uh-huh.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: We’re going to Disneyland and ride the Matterhorn?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: How does that involve air travel?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: We’re going to Disney World and ride the Matterhorn?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Penny

utterance.speaker: Leonard

utterance.speaker: Penny

utterance.speaker: Leonard

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Rabeliechtli. It means turnip light and refers to a traditional lantern hand-carved from a root vegetable and used to celebrate certain Swiss festivals. Which you will not be celebrating because, A, these festivals occur in the fall, and B, you will not be going to Switzerland.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sheldon, we’ve been through this. I’m taking Penny.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Afraid not. Do you recognize this?

utterance.speaker: Leonard

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Indeed, the roommate agreement. I call your attention to the Friendship Rider in Appendix C, Future Commitments. Number 37, in the event one friend is ever invited to visit the Large Hadron Collider, now under construction in Switzerland, he shall invite the other friend to accompany him.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, for God’s sakes.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: You actually put that in an agreement?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah. We also put in what happens if one of us wins a MacArthur Grant, or if one of us gets superpowers, or if one of us is bitten by a zombie.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: He can’t kill me, even if I turn.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Is there anything in there about if one of you gets a girlfriend?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No, that seemed a little farfetched.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sheldon, do you really expect to enforce this?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’ve lived up to all my commitments under the agreement. At least once a day I ask how you are, even though I simply don’t care. I no longer stage spontaneous biohazard drills after 10 pm And I abandoned my goal to master Tuvan throat singing.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, I know I shouldn’t ask, but what is…?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (after demonstrating)
utterance.content: I’d be much further along if I’d been allowed to practice.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Look, Sheldon, I know it’s in the agreement, and if you turn into a zombie, I promise I will not kill you. In fact, I’ll even let you eat my brains. But I am taking Penny to Switzerland.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Is that your final decision?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: It is.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Very well.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: It’s not over, is it?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What do you think?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Got a bit of traffic this morning, huh? Think it’s gonna rain? Instead of underpants, I covered my crotch with potato salad this morning. Thoughts? Okay, I know what’ll cheer you up, let’s play one of your driving games.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: All right. This game is called Traitors. I will name three historical figures, you put them in order of the heinousness of their betrayal. Benedict Arnold, Judas, Dr. Leonard Hofstadter.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You really think I belong with Benedict Arnold and Judas?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You’re right. Judas had the decency to hang himself after what he did.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Come on, Sheldon. Can’t you at least try to understand how much this means to me?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Round two, Leonard Hofstadter, Darth Vader, Rupert Murdoch.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Rupert Murdoch?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: He owns Fox, and they cancelled Firefly. Hint, he and Darth Vader are tied for number 2.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I’m sorry I couldn’t hang with you last night. I had a date with Bernadette.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I know. I saw the Tweet.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: So, what did you end up doing?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Not much. Nuked a burrito. Prayed to the Hindu god Urvashi that your bowels would loosen and your penis would droop like a willow tree.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You seen Sheldon?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: No. Is he still mad about the supercollider?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah. He thinks I betrayed him. I mean, come on, what would you guys do if you were me?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I’d take Sheldon to Switzerland.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Seriously?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Absolutely. And I’d leave him there.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: What the hell is that?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Uh, let’s see. Yup, 30 pieces of silverware.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Morning, old chum.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What’s going on?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’ve made you breakfast. Juice, coffee, and pancakes in the shape of some of your favorite fictional characters. See, here’s Frodo.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You made Frodo pancakes?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yeah, I used coconut shavings to do the hair on his feet. If you need to void your bladder before eating, I can keep them warm with this beret that I thoroughly laundered and pressed into service as a pancake cosy.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Why are you doing this?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It’s by way of an apology for my recent behaviour. I’ve had some time to reflect and I’ve come to realize that friendship is not an aggregation of written agreements. It’s a result of two people respecting and caring for each other. Butterscotch scone?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Thanks. It’s good.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: What you’re tasting is respect and affection. And about a pound of Crisco. After you’ve finished breakfast, I thought we could spend the day watching the final season of Babylon 5 with director commentary.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You hate Babylon 5.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I do. It fails as drama, science fiction, and it’s hopelessly derivative. But you like it, and you’re my friend.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, great. Still not taking you to Switzerland.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Drat. No Frodo for you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Hello.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Hello.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Alright, let’s dispense with the friendly banter, I believe you know why I’m here.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well, I always figured it was to study us, discover our weaknesses, and report back to your alien overlords.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yes, amusing. Extraordinary intelligence might well appear extraterrestrial to you, but let me be more specific. I believe you know why I’m here in the laundry room.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Better acoustics for your throat singing?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (trying it)
utterance.content: It’s actually not bad. But my true purpose in being here will be revealed in this brief PowerPoint presentation. Lights. Why Sheldon Cooper, PhD, should go to Switzerland to see the CERN supercollider. A PowerPoint presentation by Sheldon Cooper, PhD.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, for God’s sakes.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Here we have a highly gifted researcher in the field of particle physics whose work has brought him to the precipice of forever changing mankind’s understanding of the universe. AKA me. And here we have a waitress brushing her teeth with her finger. AKA you.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I’m sorry. Is this supposed to be buttering me up?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Please hold all questions to the end of the presentation. This is the Large Hadron Collider at CERN in Switzerland, the product of decades of planning and construction. It is a Mecca for physicists the world over. This is Bath and Body Works on Colorado Boulevard. They sell scented soaps and lotions, some of which contain glitter. Now, let’s see if we can match the individual to the appropriate destination.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, show’s over.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No, it’s not. I’ve got five more slides.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sheldon, this is Leonard’s decision. He invited me to Switzerland, and I intend to go.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Very well. Enjoy yourself. You’re going to be in the presence of something that I’ve dreamed of seeing for decades. I just hope you’ll be able to appreciate the magnitude of where you are and what it represents.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I’ll talk to Leonard.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You will?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yes. If it means that much to you, you should go.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (Hugging her)
utterance.content: Oh, Penny, thank you!

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: You’re welcome.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Since I rarely hug, I’m relying on your expertise regarding duration.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I think we’re there.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, good. Bye-bye.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Trust me, you can’t. I’ve tried.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: No, no, no, I’m going to have a me day. First I’m going to go to one of those spas in Koreatown, take a steam and get a massage. Then I’m going to stop at a pet store and get licked by puppies.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sheldon, I need to talk to you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: All right, my friend. Would you like some cholermus?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Some what?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Cholermus. It’s a traditional Swiss breakfast dish. I’m preparing my gastrointestinal system for the exotic cuisine of Switzerland.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You’re not going to Switzerland!

utterance.content: Oh, but I am. Didn’t Penny tell you the good news?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: She told me that you went behind my back to guilt her into letting you go instead of her.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yes, that good news.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Well, forget it. I was the one who was invited, I get to decide who goes with me, and it’s Penny, not you!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon

utterance.content: Really?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah, really.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well then, you leave me no alternative. From this moment forward, we can be roommates, but we will no longer be friends.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I’m sorry you feel that way.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I don’t think you’re fully aware of the ramifications here, Leonard.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Why don’t you enlighten me?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: With the friendship clause of our roommate agreement nullified you are no longer entitled to accompany me to go swimming at Bill Gates’ house should I be invited.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Ooh, that’s gotta sting.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Just think, this time tomorrow we’ll be in Geneva, Switzerland for our first Valentine’s Day.

utterance.speaker: Penny

utterance.content: Did that sound okay to you? Do not come in here!

utterance.speaker: Leonard

utterance.content: Great. I’ll start packing. In a minute. Oh, look, it’s the cholermus.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon

utterance.speaker: Penny

utterance.speaker: Penny

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Not my problem. I just don’t understand how this happened to me. I’m scrupulous about my hygiene. I regularly disinfect my hands, and I avoid contact with other people on general principle.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I don’t know what to tell you, Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (remembering the hug)
utterance.content: It’s you! I touched you!

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Happy Valentine’s Day.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Oh, my goodness, look at this room! Champagne! Roses! Oh, and little chocolates! This is going to be the best Valentine’s Day ever.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah, I forgot about all this.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: But I never will.
